conversation.content: I'm working [shouting] on the Banksy restoration! The one from the Bristol underpass!
Oh, that's the 2009 piece with, um, the modified epoxy resins. We actually analyzed the pigment degradation patterns using, you know, Raman spectroscopy at the conservation lab last month.
What did the spectroscopy reveal about the paint composition?
Well, he used Krylon ColorMaster aerosol with, er, a modified alkyd base. The thing is, Montana Gold caps were definitely involved for the fine detail work on the stenciling.
Those caps give such precise control. Did you identify the stencil material?
The stencils were [cry] acetate sheets, 0.5mm thickness. We found microscopic fragments embedded in the primer layer using our Leica DVM6 digital microscope at 2500x magnification.
That's [anxious] incredibly, um, detailed analysis. How do you, like, preserve the original integrity while, you know, restoring it?
We're using cyclododecane as a temporary consolidant before applying the Paraloid B-72 in xylene solution. The CDD sublimes at room temperature, leaving zero residue on the original pigments.
Cyclododecane is brilliant for that. Uh, what about the, well, underlying concrete substrate? I mean, is it stable?

The carbonation depth is, hmm, approximately 12mm according to our phenolphthalein tests. Actually, we're injecting ethyl silicate consolidant, you know, through microneedles to strengthen the substrate matrix.
Ethyl silicate penetration must be carefully controlled though.
Exactly. We monitor the [gasp loudly] penetration depth using ultrasonic pulse velocity testing. The Proceq Pundit PL-200 gives us readings every 2mm through the concrete structure.
The Pundit's resolution is impressive. What's your timeline for completion?
Four weeks total. We're documenting everything with RTI imaging— that's Reflectance Transformation Imaging— capturing 48 different light angles for complete surface topology mapping.
RTI is [whispering] fantastic for surface, um, basically for texture documentation. Are you, well, using polynomial texture mapping too?
Yes! The PTM [high-pitched] files are processed through CHI's RTIViewer software. We're generating normal maps at 300 DPI resolution for archival purposes at the Tate Modern's conservation database.
The Tate's database has strict metadata requirements.

Right, so [confidently] we follow CIDOC-CRM standards for, like, cultural heritage documentation. Every intervention is basically logged with XRF spectrometry data, honestly, down to individual pigment particles.
XRF gives such precise elemental analysis. Will this be publicly accessible?

The full technical report goes [slowly] live on ArtTechConservation.org next month. We're including hyperspectral imaging data, consolidant penetration maps, and time-lapse photogrammetry of the entire restoration process.
